channel.title: Would using JNI help speed up optical calculations in a RS bot?
channel.description: When my optical bot scans for information, it reads pixels from an int[][] (ex, (data[10][1] = 432342343). I was wondering if I were to pass the scanning into JNI's C and have it return a Point, would the scan time decrease overall? (Currently java can find a result in 200-300ms)

item.title: Would using JNI help speed up optical calculations in a RS bot?
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

I suppose you cold use OpenCV’s HaarClassifier and learn objects such as trees and monsters to use on the game. JavaCV is pretty quick and easy to use.

edit: read this http://iris.usc.edu/outlines/papers/2007/wu-nev-iccv07.pdf
might be a slightly bit of overkill for your needs but basically just take a few pictures of objects and train the classifier until it is decent enough to detect objects.

Read full topic
item.source: Would using JNI help speed up optical calculations in a RS bot?

item.title: Would using JNI help speed up optical calculations in a RS bot?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

I would honestly doubt it, Java is pretty fast as is with JIT. Of course, doing some benchmarks would help validate these claims.

Read full topic
item.source: Would using JNI help speed up optical calculations in a RS bot?

item.title: Would using JNI help speed up optical calculations in a RS bot?
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

In a word, no. Graphics related programming is calculation intensive.

Have you ascertained whether or not you’re using a ‘good’ algorithm to achieve what you’re trying to do? The second explanation, plain and simple, is that your function is poorly written.

Read full topic
item.source: Would using JNI help speed up optical calculations in a RS bot?

item.title: Would using JNI help speed up optical calculations in a RS bot?
item.dc:creator: @Entropy Entropy
item.description:
@Entropy wrote:

Well, it find probably 4-5 points in that time, then scans those 4-5 for the best match. Would JavaCV be as efficient as OpenCV?

Read full topic
item.source: Would using JNI help speed up optical calculations in a RS bot?

item.title: Would using JNI help speed up optical calculations in a RS bot?
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

You would have to profile that. Using JNI adds some overhead so if you do go down that path then you should reserve native calls for computationally expensive operations only.

Have you considered looking at C/C++ and OpenCV? I don’t know why your running time for such an operation is so high, but obviously 1/3rd of a second for the calculation of one point is not going to work.

Read full topic
item.source: Would using JNI help speed up optical calculations in a RS bot?
